instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Got a board in that has no signs of liquid damage, has magsafe light but no other signs of life. Found F7040 blown, replaced after checking that things around the ISL looked par for the course. Still no fan spin and the smell of something getting hot. Long story short in a rabbit hole removing anything that could possibly short the rail to ground <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>, isloated the part of the rail from the back light, etc. Im starting to think this board may have a CPU short and that its a donor board. Resistance between pin 1 and pin 2 of L7310 and L7320 is 0.2 Ohm. Is there any hope are should I tell the client "He's Dead Jim."?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Resistance between pin 1 and pin 2 of L7310 and L7320 is 0.2 Ohm
Why are you measuring a coil and what were you expecting?

Inject voltage on PPBUS and see what heats up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: When power is injected <CAPACITOR>C7056</CAPACITOR> gets hot beside the CPU.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Remove <CAPACITOR>C7056</CAPACITOR> and see if that clears the short, then replace it

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: There is no <CAPACITOR>C7056</CAPACITOR> in my 00165 schematic. Just rip it off, it is on PPBUS anyway and not need to replace.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27264"]There is no <CAPACITOR>C7056</CAPACITOR> in my 00165 schematic. Just rip it off, it is on PPBUS anyway and not need to replace.[/QUOTE]

This is what I get for trying to remember component numbers without a schematic in front of me. It was <CAPACITOR>C7376</CAPACITOR> when I replaced it with another cap the short was gone however it got hot with power running through it. I removed it completely and the computer turns on, is it ok to leave it off for good?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you replaced it with another cap it quite possibly just was leftover heat from the replacement or it was also damaged.

Like duke said you can leave it off for good. Its not very important as its just one of the 8 big input capacitors.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Awesome! This was the first repair for a new business client I always hate the first impressions being unrepairable! This one is solved. Thanks [USER="289"]smiba[/USER]  and [USER][/USER]
